Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of Motion Analysis System, Force Plates, EMG System, and EXAscan 3D Scanner for Research and Education in Biomechanics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1126763
Caruntu

The proposed instrumentation will support projects (7 faculty from 5 departments) to advance understanding and knowledge in biomechanics of human joints (modeling), human gait and motor control, and research-based instruction in biomechanics. 1) The original biomechanics models to be developed will contribute to new concepts of joint replacement design, implant design, joint stability, and new rehabilitation exercises that will benefit post-surgery patients. This research will investigate muscle level of activation, and contact and ligament forces in normal and deficient knees during various exercises. 2) The research on movement disturbances in autism spectrum disorders will provide potentially transformative concepts on musculoskeletal biomechanics and sensorimotor control interactions of lower limb (coordination of balance and locomotion). 3) Challenge-based instruction in biomechanics will address, in a creative and
transformative way, the integration of research and education. The requested instrumentation will equip a Biomechanics Laboratory and will broaden the research scope for all participants, allowing for new scientific problems in novel and fresh directions.

Institution.Name: The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The integrated biomechanics research instrument consisting of synchronized Vicon Motion Analysis System, AMTI OR6-6 Force Plates, and Delsys Electromyographic (EMG) System (along with a Creaform EXAscan 3D Scanner) was installed and operation started in July 2012. This instrumentation equips the Biomechanics Laboratory (Director PI Caruntu) at the University of Texas Rio Grande Valley - UTRGV (former University of Texas Pan American - UTPA). UTRGV is an institution serving underrepresented minorities and undergoing a research transition important to student success and faculty research careers. The granted instrumentation enhances the capability of conducting biomechanics research. The Biomechanics Laboratory is the only one in Rio Grande Valley and south of San Antonio.

Intellectual Merit: The granted instrumentation was used for projects advancing understanding and knowledge in human joints biomechanics, Total Knee Replacement (TKR) design, and rehabilitation exercises. These projects investigated muscle level of activation, contact forces, and ligament forces in normal and deficient knees. Experimental biomechanics data from the Biomechanics Laboratory along with biomechanics models developed at UTRGV produced preliminary data regarding 1) human knee joint during squat exercise and 2) knee ligament viscoelastic effect on dynamic testing of knee joint. The preliminary data allows for new government agency proposals to be submitted for future funding. The deep squat exercise is one of the most demanding exercise for the knee joint. Since actual TKR are limited to small to moderate knee flexion angles (activities such as walking, and from standing to sitting and back), there is a need of new TKR designs to allow for deep knee flexion angle activities. In this perspective, the granted instrumentation is used for researching new concepts of TKR design, implant design, joint stability, and new rehabilitation exercises benefiting post-surgery patients. The Biomechanics Laboratory brings together faculty from several departments from the College of Engineering and Computer Science and medical doctors from Rio Grande Valley (and, in the near future, faculty from the newly formed Medical School within UTRGV). A new project, namely Visualization of Biomechanics Data, has been initiated. 

Broader Impact: The Biomechanics Laboratory significantly impacts UTRGV transition towards becoming a research emerging institution. 1) A total number of 5 faculty from 3 departments collaborated/collaborate on research projects using the biomechanics instrumentation. These three departments are Mechanical Engineering, Manufacturing Engineering, and Computer Science. The projects were/are carried out with undergraduate (UG) and graduate (GR) students, 85% of whom are Hispanic. 2) Two GR students, under the thesis option and reporting biomechanics research, graduated with MS in Mechanical Engineering degrees. This biomechanics research addressed squat exercise, and viscoelastic ligaments in knee joint dynamic exercises. 3) This research has been disseminated through five peer-reviewed conference papers published and presented, and one technical presentation only, at the American Society of Mechanical Engineering (ASME) congresses and design conferences. 4) It has also been disseminated through poster presentations at HESTEC, annual event at UTRGV. Two posters reporting biomechanics research have been awarded First Place of GR poster competition, and Third Place of UG poster competition. 5) A new UG elective course, namely MECE 4381 Experimental Orthopaedic Biomechanics, offered by the PI, has been added to the Mechanical Engineering curriculum. During the granting period the elective has been offered three times and a total number of 65 ...

These three departments are Mechanical Engineering, Manufacturing Engineering, and Computer Science. The projects were/are carried out with undergraduate (UG) and graduate (GR) students, 85% of whom are Hispanic. 2) Two GR students, under the thesis option and reporting biomechanics research, graduated with MS in Mechanical Engineering degrees. This biomechanics research addressed squat exercise, and viscoelastic ligaments in knee joint dynamic exercises. 3) This research has been disseminated through five peer-reviewed conference papers published and presented, and one technical presentation only, at the American Society of Mechanical Engineering (ASME) congresses and design conferences. 4) It has also been disseminated through poster presentations at HESTEC, annual event at UTRGV. Two posters reporting biomechanics research have been awarded First Place of GR poster competition, and Third Place of UG poster competition. 5) A new UG elective course, namely MECE 4381 Experimental Orthopaedic Biomechanics, offered by the PI, has been added to the Mechanical Engineering curriculum. During the granting period the elective has been offered three times and a total number of 65 UG students have benefited from this course and have used the biomechanics instrumentation. 6) An existing GR course, namely MECE 6335 Orthopaedic Biomechanics, has been enhanced by adding two new biomechanics labora...
